Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Fundamental Study of Impacts of Manufacturing Processes and Automation on Material Properties of Composite Products

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fiber reinforced polymer composites, by virtue of their high stiffness and high strength-to-weight ratio, are increasingly used in a wide range of industries such as transportation, marine, wind energy, aerospace, and construction. Automation of composite laminates manufacturing is instrumental in meeting the growing demand for composites and promises to revolutionize composite-dependent industries. However, the few existing layup automation systems are prohibitively expensive and are not fully optimized for product quality. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research aims to establish a systematic framework that will assist in solving the critical challenges in automation, monitoring and control for composite laminates manufacturing. The framework will establish the necessary fundamental understanding of relationships among composite constituents' properties, principal composite manufacturing processes and automation, and fabricated product quality. The new knowledge will help increase productivity and quality of composite laminates manufacturing. Results from this research will assist U.S. composite manufacturers and benefit the U.S. economy and society. This GOALI research employs a multi-disciplinary approach (involving solid mechanics, composites engineering, control theory and robotics) to achieve the research objectives. In addition, it incorporates research goals with industrial needs and helps broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research and enhance engineering education.

This research will fill the knowledge gap in the complex interactions between fabrication parameters and laminas' temperature- and time-dependent properties (viscoelasticity and tackiness) and their impact on the properties of composite laminates (i.e., a stack of multi-directional laminas arranged to exhibit specific mechanical properties). The research team will (1) create multi-physics manufacturing process models to predict impacts of process parameters on manufacturing induced defects and final product quality, and conduct experiments to verify the models; (2) gain an understanding on the roles of quality inspection and optimal control in increasing productivity through manufacturing dynamics simulations; and (3) obtain the knowledge on how to control the physical process to ensure the product quality as a guideline for manufacturing practices.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fiber reinforced polymer composites, by virtue of their high stiffness and high strength-to-weight ratio, are increasingly used in a wide range of industries such as transportation, marine, wind energy, aerospace, and construction. Automation of composite laminates manufacturing is instrumental in meeting the growing demand for composites and promises to revolutionize composite-dependent industries. The goal of the research is to optimize the composite product manufacturing process to improve quality and throughput. This research aims to establish the scientific and technological foundation for understanding the process parameters and their impacts on composite product mechanical properties and provide a fundamental understanding of quality inspection strategies and optimal control schemes.

With the support of this NSF grant, a novel framework with integrated experimental studies, simulation analysis, automated device design, efficient manufacturing work cell analysis and testing for the new automated method is developed.

(1)   An optimum process condition for manufacturing Hexcel 299-947-330 laminate on a hot press machine based on inter-laminar shear strength is explored through experiment. The experiment results enable the understanding of the property of the carbon fiber prepreg and contribute to enhancing the understanding of the automated tape laying manufacturing process. To increase the process throughput, the project explores the potential to minimize or eliminate the need for autoclave curing by using in-situ curing during layup.

(2)   The microstructure of prepreg was modeled in the commercial finite element analysis software ABAQUS. Finite element simulations are utilized to advance the fundamental understanding of the relationship among composite materials properties, principal composite manufacturing processes (including processes relevant to automation) and fabricated products mechanical properties in order to enable high quality and high volume production and provide economic solutions that can fit the needs of composite manufactures.

(3)   Based on the simulations and experiments, the range of process parameters, e.g., pressures, temperatures, and speeds of the automated tape laying are determined and incorporated into a higher-level system modeling for optimal control.

(4)   A cost-effective automated device for hand layup is designed and the prototype device is built. The device is designed to create uniform test samples while holding the application pressure and roller speed parameters constant. With the understanding that the composite material properties are directionally dependent, an angle changing component is incorporated. These features make the produced test samples much closer to the composites produced in industry.

(5)   A data enabled mathematical model is built for composite work cell. The work cell performance diagnostics is carried out based on the math model of composite work cells using automatic robotic loading/unloading and layup. A robotic/gantry scheduling and control method is developed by using reinforcement learning to improve the automatic layup efficiency and quality. An on-line quality inspection and system level optimal control with robotic loading/unloading strategies are designed and are applied to more complex scenarios.

(6)   A lab testbed is built to incorporate the designed automated layup device and robotic loading/unloading. Optimal control of robotic movement is validated.

This award has broader impacts on education and outreach. The research findings of this project have been incorporated in the curricula at Stony Brook University and benefit both undergraduate and graduate teaching. The project has trained one PhD student (female), three MS students (two of them are female students), and two undergraduate students. The PI has actively partnered with the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Program at Stony Brook University, which is designed to increase the numbers of traditionally underrepresented minority students who pursue degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) majors. The PI has also collaborated with local high schools in long island, NY area. Three K-12 students have been actively involved in the research activities on this project and the outcomes have been presented at various science competitions and science fairs. The results from the project have also been broadly disseminated to the academic community and the general public through conference/journal publications. This award has led to the publication of four journal papers and two conference papers, and the accomplishment of three MS theses and one senior design project.

Modified by: Qing Chang
